messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app.py: from flask import Flask, jsonify, request
if email not in users or contact_email not in users:
if email not in users or contact_email not in users:
if email not in users or group_name not in users[email]['groups'] or participant_email not in users:
if email not in users or group_name not in users[email]['groups'] or participant_email not in users:
if email not in users or group_name not in users[email]['groups'] or admin_email not in users:
if sender_email not in users or receiver_email not in users:

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a 'users' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing user information. The keys of this dictionary will be the user's email and the values will be another dictionary containing the user's password, profile picture, status message, privacy settings, blocked contacts, and groups. Write tests to ensure that the Flask application is set up correctly and that the 'users' dictionary is functioning as expected.

Step 2: Implement the user registration and authentication features. This includes creating routes for signing up and forgotten password recovery. The sign-up route should take an email and password as input, store them in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. The forgotten password recovery route should take an email as input, check if it exists in the 'users' dictionary, and return the associated password. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 3: Implement the user profile features. This includes creating routes for setting profile pictures and status messages, and for updating privacy settings. The profile picture and status message routes should take an email, picture, and message as input respectively, update the corresponding fields in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. The privacy settings route should take an email and a privacy setting as input, update the corresponding field in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 4: Implement the contact management features. This includes creating routes for blocking/unblocking contacts and for creating, editing, and managing groups. The block/unblock routes should take two emails as input, update the 'blocked contacts' field of the first email in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. The group routes should take an email, a group name, and a list of emails as input, update the 'groups' field of the first email in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 5: Implement the messaging features. This includes creating routes for sending and receiving real-time text messages, for updating message read receipts, for encrypting and decrypting messages, and for sharing images. The message routes should take two emails and a message as input, update a 'messages' dictionary (which should be created in this step), and return a success message. The read receipt, encryption, and image sharing routes should function similarly. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 6: Implement the group chat features. This includes creating routes for creating group chats with a name and picture, for adding or removing participants, and for updating admin roles and permissions. The group chat routes should take an email, a group name, a picture, and a list of emails as input, update the 'groups' field of the first email in the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. The participant and admin routes should function similarly. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting image statuses visible for a limited time and for controlling who can see the status. The status route should take an email, an image, and a time limit as input, update a 'statuses' dictionary (which should be created in this step), and return a success message. The visibility route should take an email and a list of emails as input, update the 'statuses' dictionary, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 8: Implement the web application feature. This includes creating a route for accessing the application from a browser. The web application route should return a webpage that allows users to interact with all the features of the application. Write tests to ensure that this route is functioning as expected.

Step 9: Implement the connectivity and offline mode features. This includes creating a route for updating the online/offline status of a user and for queuing messages when a user is offline. The online/offline route should take an email and a status as input, update the 'users' dictionary, and return a success message. The message queuing route should function similarly to the message sending route from step 5, but it should also check the online status of the recipient and queue the message if they are offline. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

Step 10: Finally, review all the code and tests to ensure that everything is functioning as expected. Run all the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests are passing, the application is ready to be deployed.
step: Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting image statuses visible for a limited time and for controlling who can see the status. The status route should take an email, an image, and a time limit as input, update a 'statuses' dictionary (which should be created in this step), and return a success message. The visibility route should take an email and a list of emails as input, update the 'statuses' dictionary, and return a success message. Write tests to ensure that these routes are functioning as expected.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
